attributes.value: Rick Broadbent

As I follow Chris Reynolds Gordon down the first floor corridor of a £27 million house, nestled between the Colombian consulate and the Swedish ambassador’s residence, we pass an ornate room full of mattresses. He smiles and closes the door as we walk past. This is the habitat of a man who is making his fortune from hosting “elite” sex parties in one of London’s wealthiest postcodes, and the room was the venue of his latest sex party. He has not read Fifty Shades of Grey but, he says, “I’m living it.”

The “elite” have been chosen from those who, through his Heaven SX website and social media, apply for invitations to his parties. Most applicants, he claims, are discarded because of paunch and age, and only the best-looking get to pay around £100 for a ticket. They drink, chat and then, at midnight, the women get changed into lingerie. “It’s loads of girls, all giggling, putting on their stockings, hair flowing,” he explains. “Then they walk in, the guys go, ‘Wow,’ and the mood changes. They all start disappearing and, before you know it, there are 30 girls on a bed and designer gear everywhere. When I pull it off I can’t believe I created it.”

Reynolds Gordon, 30, has a light beard, wears a white T-shirt, jeans and no shoes, and while self-satisfaction oozes from him, it seems to mask a fragility. We are sitting at an elegant dining table in a crimson room that mixes old and new. Oil paintings in gold frames adorn the walls. There is a sofa with a tiger-skin throw draped over it. He speaks quickly in middle-class tones. “The people coming to the parties are probably people you work with,” he says. “You’d be shocked. Absolutely shocked. It’s teachers, doctors, lawyers, journalists.”

His parties cater largely to couples and single girls. There are different formats – three women to two men; all women; the masquerade ball. Everyone has to be under 35. The organisers like the women to make the first move and there is a “zero tolerance policy” if any one of them complains to security. Photography is banned unless it is a “Heaven Sinema” party, where you get a nice DVD. Some people, “especially celebrities”, wear masks. “We’ve had Grammy winners,” Reynolds Gordon boasts. “We had a model who was on the cover of Vogue. This is going on all over London. Sex is a drug.”

This building, 33 Portland Place, comes complete with stained-glass billiard room and hydraulic wall; Amy Winehouse shot the video for Rehab here. Reynolds Gordon makes a cup of tea and sits down on a green chaise longue that was used in filming The King’s Speech. He says he pays astronomical rent, and will have to move because the owner, his friend and convicted fraudster Edward “Fast Eddie” Davenport, got out of prison last year, to be faced with a £12 million confiscation order.

Reynolds Gordon was born Chris Webb in 1985. His father was a chef at the Hilaire restaurant in London and heading for a Michelin star. Then, when he was four, his parents divorced and he went to stay with his grandmother in Swansea. After two years he moved to Essex to live with his mother, Jenny, and John Reynolds, who would become both his stepfather and athletics coach. Chris Reynolds, as he was now named, had a talent for running and, at 14, was the English Schools 1,500 metres champion. He added three more schools headlines and by 2003 was the fastest 18-year-old in Britain and destined for the Olympics.

Or would have been were it not for a bitter row with his mother and stepfather, which he says started with his refusal, because he already had an unconditional offer from Swansea University, to go on a computer course at another college. It culminated in his parents changing the locks to the house and an 18-month rift that meant for a while he was living out of the back of his car on a diet of fish and chips. He was 19 and had lost his parents, his coach and probably his running career.

He did go to university, and eventually he tried to make amends. “I wrote them a letter, basically saying life is too short and you never know what’s going to happen. I remember writing it with tears streaming down my face and smudging the ink.”

They were, thankfully, reconciled by the time his mother died on the night of his 21st birthday party. “She wouldn’t come down and we thought she had flu, but she’d been wrongly diagnosed and was bleeding in her stomach. It was only when I got to the hospital and the nurse said, ‘We’re doing all we can,’ that I thought, ‘F***, this could be serious.’ I cried a lot that night too and decided that I wanted to make her proud.”

His inheritance was £360,000. It was, he admits, the worst time in history to give a “driven but not very knowledgeable” boy that sort of sum. He attended a seminar and gave £42,000 to some “very big boys” who taught him how to trade. “The market was so crazy. Everything was f***ed.” When the Lehman Brothers went down, he “lost a fortune in three seconds, but then I regrouped. I went short on everything. I could not understand how you could not make money.” He made, he says, an astronomical amount.

Meanwhile, Reynolds Gordon still wanted to make the 2008 Olympics in Beijing and was running 50 miles a week at a winter training camp in Potchefstroom in South Africa. Then he suffered a foot injury and his Beijing dreams were over. He revelled in the life of a playboy. On his girlfriend’s 21st birthday, he flew her to Vegas on a whim.

Over the next few years, he invested in properties in Dubai, Morocco and Egypt. Unfortunately, he had not banked on the recession, or the fact that those properties might not ever get built, and ended up with just £2,000 and an overdraft to his name.

He decided the answer to his problems was to become a diamond trader. As you do. He talked his way into getting proof of funds to the extent that he went to Russia to meet executives from a major diamond group. He says he had committed to buying in such large quantities that he could use the discount to make money after passing on a smaller discount to his backers.

“Risk was not in my vocabulary. This guy wrote me a covering letter for £390 million, signed off by this bank. My girlfriend at that time was saying, ‘Are you nuts? You’re going to Moscow with a bag that says you’re worth £390 million. You could get shot.’ I got picked up in a red-plated [for government vehicles] car and was put up at the President Hotel.”

He says he met President Putin and certainly had a photograph taken with his mentor, secretary of state Pavel Borodin. Not surprisingly, the deal foundered, which is how Reynolds Gordon found himself back at the family home in Essex and wandering into the local woods late one night.

He does not remember the genesis of the argument with his stepfather, but he remembers putting his hand through the wall of the house in Chigwell. “I was trying to hang on, but my relationship with my girlfriend was breaking up and my running was going to pot. When you grow up feeling special and then everything goes wrong it is so unbelievably demoralising. I literally smashed up everything I had and said, ‘That’s it. I’m ending it right now.’

“I wrote a note – ‘Sorry for being such a f***-up’. I was in a frenzy and I went out, slammed the door and walked into the forest. I was ready to go. I was crying so much and just stood there. The minutes passed. Maybe 40. And I calmed down. I went home. A lot of people who commit suicide can’t see a future. I couldn’t see a girlfriend, prospects, but I guess there was a spark there. People think the opposite of happiness is unhappiness but it’s not – the opposite of happiness is ingratitude.”

Reynolds Gordon wrote “360 million” on a scrap of paper as a mission statement, a 10,000 per cent mark-up on his inheritance, and added the Gordon in homage to the Gordon Gekko character played by Michael Douglas in the film Wall Street.

Still close to his stepfather-cum-coach, the Olympics in London were now his aim. He went back to train in South Africa and made rapid improvements. He felt ready. In 2011, the trials for the European Indoor Championships were taking place in Sheffield. Reynolds Gordon was second in his 800 metres heat but only sixth in the final. He was six seconds and five years off his personal best. “I knew it was over then. I went home and cried for two days. I had no money left. I thought, ‘What do I do now?’”

He says his stepfather got a new girlfriend at about the same time and their relationship flatlined. “We were never the same again, which is a shame because I’ve never loved anybody more in my life.” Now they do not speak.

He took a job as a broker with a company that specialised in eco-friendly products and the money, he says, started rolling in again. He lived in a gated house in Surrey and claims he had ten girlfriends (“Because if I had seven they’d say you only ever stay on a Monday”), but his life was slowly imploding.

When his boss failed to turn up for work one day he realised there was no substance behind the business. His finances crumbled and there was a period when he was homeless, squatting in a basement changing room of a friend’s business in the City. “People would knock on the door of the cubicle wanting a shower and I’d be in there in my sleeping bag, trying to get up.”

Through another businessman friend he met a girl who said she wanted to become an escort. She told him she was nervous and asked if he would go with her to her first job. It was his entry to the sex trade. “We turned up at this amazing apartment and there was a 50-year-old guy and a girl who was so attractive that I couldn’t speak. That’s when I realised he had booked her as his girlfriend and us as his foursome.

“As I left, the girl put a piece of paper in my hand and said, ‘You should be working with me.’ So I did. The money was incredible. I went from the office basement to an apartment in Kensington within the space of four weeks. It was the most f***ed-up period of my life. It was mostly threesomes. I was flying to places first class. I was getting paid to have sex with off-the-scale women.”
Ultimately, the post-coital realisation that this was a shallow existence contrasted dramatically with his pre-Olympic aspirations. Again, he says he hit rock bottom.
“The London Olympics were supposed to be all about me. And there I was. I would be with a woman who’d paid me and I’d be faking it. I was totally lost.”
He gave up life as a gigolo and went back to living with his grandmother in Swansea. He took a job packing boxes for Amazon.

The following year, he went back to London. Another business plan had fomented while he was in Wales. In London, he had been to swingers parties for fun and decided that he could make money from them if he set his prices low enough to attract young, beautiful people.

The first party was a financial disaster, but soon he was hiring mansions and hotel suites. He was introduced to Eddie Davenport, who had run Gatecrasher balls for rich teenagers in the Eighties. When one hotel turfed out Reynolds Gordon and his revellers, he rang Davenport and a scantily clad convoy wound its way to 33 Portland Place.

You sense he likes to shock, but would his mother be proud if she could see him now? His relationships with his father and stepfather have long since frozen over and Reynolds Gordon looks sheepish. “I don’t think my nan knows; my biological father is not happy; my stepfather is not happy; a lot of people are not happy. Why should I care what they think? I’ve had no family for years. Follow your bliss and make sure you are not hurting anyone. The bottom line is no king, no parent, no teacher can tell you what corridors to walk down.”

He wonders if “maybe I wasn’t loved enough”, but has been in loving relationships, both with his family and girlfriends. Would he like to have kids and settle down? “I do worry about that,” he says. “When you have orgies with 50 unbelievably hot girls then you tend to think, ‘How do I settle down?’ Sex is great. It’s an important part of life. It’s what we are genetically designed to do, but I view it as the sugar on top. If you live on a diet of pure sugar you will not be a well man.”

There are various businesses now – from watches to cars – built from contacts he has made, often indirectly, from the sex parties, a sort of naked networking. He says he would like to be known as the entrepreneur who declared war on depression.

“You can have cancer or be a paraplegic and wake up every day and think you’re going to enjoy the time you have. And then you can have cars, money, women, the perfect house and all the things society and magazines say equal success, but you hate yourself. You tell me: who’s in a better position? It’s not about reality; it’s about how you interpret reality.

“Growing up, I cared a lot about what people thought about me. Now I’ve realised you can’t please everybody. Some people may think I’ve had the courage of my convictions and others might think, ‘He runs sex parties and it’s disgusting.’ I find it beautiful that people are nuns and I find it beautiful that people dress up in rubber.
“At the end of the day, the people judging me are only saying that because of what they have been taught is normal. And when people lose their inhibitions here, it’s normal, too.”

shortHeadline: Let's keep A levels but scrap outdated GCSEs
standfirst: After 10 years helping others to cycling glory, Geraint Thomas has finally won the Tour de France. Simon Barnes hangs out with the Welsh hero at home in Cardiff
